Each question carries equal weight. You are advised to initially spend no more than 45 minutes on each question and then to return to any incomplete questions if you have time at the end. An indication of the number of marks allocated to parts of questions is shown in square brackets. No calculator is permitted in this examination. Page 1 Turn over No Calculator Section A 1. (a) For the vectors a = (1, 2, 4) and b = (3, 5, 7) calculate (i) a · b; (ii) the line parallel to a through the point (1, 1, 1); (iii) a × b; and (iv) the plane containing the points A = (1, 2, 4) and B = (3, 5, 7) and C = (1, 1, 1). [8] (b) Let s = − √ 2 2 (1 + i) and t = 16e − 2 3 πi. Determine (i) s in modulus-argument form, giving the principal value of the argument; (ii) t−1 and st−1 (s multiplied by the complex conjugate of t−1) giving your answers in exponential form with the principal value of the argument; (iii) s29 in exponential form, and providing the principal value of the argument; and (iv) the fourth roots of t in exponential form with principal value of the argument. [8] (c) (i) Use the Gaussian elimination method to determine the solution set to the following system of simultaneous linear equations: 3x + 3y − 3z = 1, x − 2y + 3z = 1, 2x + 4y − 4z = 1. [7] (ii) Give an example of a system of three simultaneous linear equations in three vari- ables which has a solution set with infinitely many elements. [2] A36781 Page 2 Turn over No Calculator 2. (a) Let α ∈ C have positive imaginary part b > 0. Show that the locus of points on the Argand diagram which satisfy (z + z) 2 = 2(αz + αz) is a parabola. Determine its focal length and vertex. [5] (b) Assume the homogeneous system of simultaneous linear equations a11x + a12y + a13z = 0, a21x + a22y + a23z = 0, a31x + a32y + a33z = 0, has solution x = a, y = b, z = c. Now assume that d1, d2, d3 ∈ R are fixed and not all zero and consider the following system of linear equations: a11x + a12y + a13z = d1, a21x + a22y + a23z = d2, a31x + a32y + a33z = d3. (1) Let A =     a11 a12 a13 a21 a22 a23 a31 a32 a33     . Which of the following statements are true? Either give a proof or present a counterexam- ple. [See next page.] A36781 Page 4 Turn over No Calculator (i) x = p, y = q, z = r is a solution to (1) if and only if x = a + p, y = b + q, z = c + r is a solution to (1). (ii) If det A = 0, then there is a unique solution to (1). (iii) If (a, b, c) ̸= (0, 0, 0), then (1) has infinitely many solutions. [9] (c) Suppose that A ∈ M4×4(R). Write down the elementary matrix E which when we calcu- late EA results in a matrix in which (i) row 1 of A is swapped with row 4 of A; (ii) row 3 of A is multiplied by 3; (iii) row 2 of A is added to row 4 of A. [6] (d) Suppose that n ≥ 2 and A ∈ Mnn(R) is an invertible n × n matrix. Prove that det(adj(A)) = det(A) n−1 where adj(A) denotes the adjoint of A. [You may use facts about the adjoint of A that are proved in the lecture notes so long as you explain carefully what you have used.] [5] A36781 Page 5 Turn over No Calculator 4. (a) Suppose that V and W are finite-dimensional vector spaces over the field F. Assume that U is a subspace of V and T : V → W is a linear transformation. Let Y = {T (u) | u ∈ U} and Z = {z ∈ V | T (z) ∈ T (U)}. (i) Show that Y is a subspace of W . (ii) Prove that Z = ker(T ) +U , where ker(T ) is the kernel of T . (iii) Show that dimF U = dimF Y if and only if ker(T ) ∩U = {0}. [13] (b) Let V = R3, W = R3 and T : V → W be defined by T ((v1, v2, v3)) = (2v1 + 2v2 + 2v3, 2v1 + v3, 4v1 + 2v2 + 3v3). (i) Show that T is a linear transformation. (ii) Determine a basis for the image of T , and explain why it is a basis. (iii) Determine the dimension of ker(T ), dimR ker(T ).
